contentrichtext.text: {{Priesthoods of ancient Rome}} In [[ancient Rome]], the '''''quindecimviri sacris faciundis''''' were the fifteen (''quindecim'') members of a [[Collegium (ancient Rome)|college (''collegium'')]] with priestly duties. Most notably they guarded the [[Sibylline Books]], scriptures which they consulted and interpreted at the request of the [[Roman Senate|Senate]]. This ''collegium'' also oversaw the worship of any foreign gods which were introduced to Rome. Originally these duties had been performed by ''duumviri'' (or ''duoviri''), two men of [[Patrician (ancient Rome)|patrician]] status. Their number was increased to ten by a Licinio-Sextian law in 367 BCE, which also stipulated that half of these priests were to be [[plebs|plebeian]]. During the [[Roman Republic#Middle Republic|Middle Republic]], members of the college were admitted through [[cooption]].
